sentence: What does it take for a company to get upwards of 20 ‘Buy’ ratings at once from Wall Street’s top analysts?
Salesforce.com (CRM – Research Report) found out earlier this week, after releasing its Q4 2018 earnings report.
The earnings were widely anticipated, as CRM shares have shown consistent growth over the long term – up 27% over the last year, and 155% over the last five years.
The company, known for its cloud-based marketing and software products, managed to both hit and miss the expectations.
Salesforce had the good fortune of heading into earnings season with a firm reputation for delivering growth and profits, and on that count it did not disappoint.
The headline Q4 numbers were impressive.
The year-ago quarter showed an EPS of 47 cents; the forecast for this report was 56 cents, and the actual result reported was 70 cents.
Revenues were also notable, coming in at $3.60 billion, well above the $3.56 billion estimate, and a solid 26% year-over-year gain.
You would think that those sort of quarterly numbers would have given CRM shares a boost in the markets, but the stock declined 3.6% after the release.
Forward guidance explains the drop – company management’s forecast numbers for Q1 were just under the markets’ expected benchmarks.
Wall Street had anticipated Q1 revenue guidance of $3.72 billion, but the company would only commit to $3.67 billion.
Company guidance put Q1 EPS estimates at 60 to 61 cents, against an expectation of 62 cents.
In keeping with the theme of ‘mixed messaging,’ Salesforce guidance for 2020 is stronger, and the company expects full-year revenues of $26 to $28 billion by 2023.

While traders’ initial reaction to the quarterly earnings was to pull back, top market analysts took a day to review the numbers before weighing in – and their collective wisdom is taking a much more upbeat view of CRM.

Six the first seven analysts on the list appear among the top analysts in the TipRanks database:

RBC Capital’s Ross MacMillan (Track Record & Ratings) saw fit to raise his price target on CRM, setting it at $183, citing the Q4 EPS and revenue beats, as well as noting that the weak guidance given improves for the second half of 2019.
MacMillan is the #2 rated analyst in the TipRanks database, with an eye-opening 86% success rate and 30% average return on his ratings.
His price target suggests a 16% upside to CRM shares.
Brian Schwartz (Track Record & Ratings), of Oppenheimer, ranked #6 overall among Wall Street analysts, has also set a ‘Buy’ rating for Salesforce.

He elaborates in his comments: “While the F4Q results and F1Q guidance may not have lived up to high investor expectations, we believe salesforce.com is executing very well and see the F4Q business metrics … lending good support to our thesis that Salesforce.com’s business can continue producing steady share gains, durable growth, and increasing cash flow.” Schwartz’s price target, $180, suggests a 14% upside to this stock.
Additional support for CRM comes from #7 ranked analyst John Difucci (Track Record & Ratings), from Jefferies.
Difucci notes the Q4 earnings and revenue beats, acknowledges that Q1 estimates were disappointing, and points out that FY2020 estimates were bumped higher than expected.
Of Salesforce’s current status, he said it “remains well positioned to fulfil its long-term goals.” Like MacMillan and Schwartz, Difucci sets an aggressive price target.
His $189 target suggests a 20% upside potential for CRM.
Judging by performance, CRM deserves the high ratings it’s been getting.
The stock is up 15% year-to-date, and has gained 122% over the last 36 months.
Since the Q4 earnings, the analyst consensus is a ‘Strong Buy,’ based on 26 ‘buys’ and 2 ‘holds.’ The stock currently trades at $156.
The average price target of $183 implies an upside of 17%.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
